use: Used in Ayurvedic medicine for colds, cough, and flu. Also has religious significance in Hindu households.
waterNeeds: Moderate; water when top inch of soil feels dry
careTips: Pinch off flower buds to encourage leaf growth. Prune regularly to maintain bushy growth. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Dry leaves in shade and store in airtight container. Fresh leaves can be refrigerated for up to a week.
growthForm: Perennial herb growing to 30-60 cm tall
specification: Considered sacred in Hinduism. Different varieties include Krishna Tulsi (purple leaves) and Rama Tulsi (green leaves).

use: Used in traditional medicine for skin diseases, fever, and infections. Young leaves used in cooking. Oil used in cosmetics and as natural pesticide.
careTips: Tolerates poor soil. Fertilize minimally. Protect young plants from frost.
storageTips: Dry leaves in shade and store in airtight containers. Neem oil should be stored in dark bottles.
growthForm: Evergreen tree growing up to 15-20 meters
specification: Known as 'village pharmacy' due to its numerous medicinal properties. Can live for 150-200 years.

use: Rhizomes used as spice in cooking, in religious ceremonies, and for medicinal purposes like anti-inflammation and wound healing.
waterNeeds: High; keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged
careTips: Plant in rich, well-draining soil. Mulch to retain moisture. Harvest when leaves turn yellow.
storageTips: Store fresh rhizomes in a cool, dark place or refrigerate. Dried powder in airtight containers.
growthForm: Perennial herb growing to 1 meter tall
specification: Contains curcumin, which gives it bright yellow color and medicinal properties. Grows best in temperatures between 20-30°C.

use: High in Vitamin C. Used in Ayurvedic medicine for digestion, diabetes, and immunity. Fruits eaten fresh or processed.
careTips: Prune after fruiting. Apply organic manure annually. Protect from strong winds.
storageTips: Fresh fruits last 1-2 weeks in refrigeration. Can be preserved in salt water or made into preserves.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 8-18 meters
specification: Extremely high vitamin C content - one fruit contains as much vitamin C as 2-3 oranges. Fruits are harvested in autumn.

use: Gel used for skin care, burns, and wounds. Also used in beverages and food products.
waterNeeds: Low; allow soil to dry completely between watering
sunlightNeeds: Bright indirect light to partial sun
careTips: Plant in well-draining soil. Repot when rootbound. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Fresh gel can be refrigerated for up to a week. Can be frozen in ice cube trays.
growthForm: Succulent with thick, fleshy leaves growing in a rosette
specification: Contains over 75 active compounds. Inner leaf gel is clear and soothing. Outer leaf contains aloin which has laxative properties.

use: Root used in Ayurveda as adaptogen for stress, anxiety, and improving energy levels.
careTips: Grows in poor soil. Space plants 60 cm apart. Protect from excessive moisture.
storageTips: Harvest roots after 1 year. Dry thoroughly and store in airtight containers.
growthForm: Erect shrub growing up to 1.5 meters tall
specification: Known as 'Indian Ginseng'. Berries can be used for seed propagation. Contains withanolides with medicinal properties.

use: Used in religious ceremonies, as garden ornamentals, and as companion plants to repel pests.
waterNeeds: Moderate; allow top soil to dry between watering
careTips: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms. Can be grown from seeds or cuttings.
storageTips: Flowers can be dried and used for garlands. Seeds can be collected when flowers dry on the plant.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 0.5-1 meter tall
specification: Widely used in Diwali and other Hindu ceremonies. Contains lutein which is beneficial for eye health.

use: Used in cooking for its citrus flavor, in teas, and in essential oils for aromatherapy.
careTips: Divide clumps every 2-3 years. Cut back to 15 cm occasionally to promote fresh growth.
storageTips: Fresh stalks can be refrigerated for up to 3 weeks. Can be frozen or dried for longer storage.
growthForm: Perennial grass growing in clumps up to 1-1.5 meters tall
specification: Contains citral which gives it distinctive lemon scent. Also acts as natural mosquito repellent.

use: National flower of India. Used in religious ceremonies. Seeds, young leaves, and rhizomes eaten as food.
waterNeeds: Very high; aquatic plant that needs standing water
careTips: Plant in containers with no drainage holes filled with heavy clay soil. Water depth should be 15-30 cm above soil.
storageTips: Seeds can be dried and stored. Rhizomes can be harvested and stored like potatoes.
growthForm: Aquatic perennial with rhizomes anchored in mud
specification: Flowers and leaves are water-repellent due to the 'lotus effect'. All parts of the plant are used in Ayurvedic medicine.

use: Seeds used for oil and spice. Leaves used as vegetable. Oil cake used as animal feed and fertilizer.
waterNeeds: Moderate; sensitive to both drought and waterlogging
careTips: Sow directly in well-draining soil. Thin seedlings to 15 cm apart. Harvest when pods turn yellow.
storageTips: Store seeds in airtight containers in cool, dry place. Oil should be stored away from direct light.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 1-2 meters tall
specification: Cold-pressed mustard oil is commonly used in North Indian cooking. Also used in crop rotation for its bio-fumigation properties.

use: National tree of India with religious significance. Bark and roots used in traditional medicine.
careTips: Not suitable for home growing due to massive size. Young plants need protection from frost.
storageTips: Not applicable for home storage; primarily an outdoor specimen tree.
growthForm: Evergreen tree with aerial roots that can spread over hectares
specification: Can live for several hundred years. The Great Banyan in Howrah is over 250 years old and covers an area of 14,500 square meters.

use: Flowers used in religious ceremonies, perfumes, and garlands. Also used to flavor tea.
careTips: Regular pruning after flowering. Apply balanced fertilizer during growing season.
storageTips: Fresh flowers last only a few days. Can be dried or used to make potpourri.
growthForm: Evergreen vine or shrub growing up to 2-3 meters tall
specification: Flowers open at night and release strongest fragrance in evening. Several varieties grown in India include single and double-flowered forms.

use: Used in Ayurveda for improving memory, reducing anxiety, and treating epilepsy.
careTips: Grows well in shallow water or very moist soil. Can be grown indoors in containers with no drainage.
storageTips: Fresh leaves can be refrigerated briefly. Usually dried and stored in airtight containers for medicinal use.
growthForm: Creeping herb with small white flowers
specification: Contains bacosides which support cognitive function. Often confused with Centella asiatica, which is also called Brahmi in northern India.

use: Sacred tree in Buddhism and Hinduism. Bark, fruit, and leaves used in traditional medicine.
careTips: Not suitable for home growing due to massive size and invasive roots. Young plants need protection from frost.
storageTips: Not applicable for home storage; primarily an outdoor specimen tree.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 30 meters tall
specification: Distinctive heart-shaped leaves with long drip tips. Buddha is said to have attained enlightenment under this tree.

use: Fruit used in cooking and traditional medicine, particularly for diabetes management.
waterNeeds: Moderate; water when top inch of soil feels dry
careTips: Provide trellis for climbing. Add compost before planting. Harvest when fruits are still green.
storageTips: Fresh fruits can be refrigerated for up to a week. Can be blanched and frozen for longer storage.
growthForm: Annual climbing vine growing up to 5 meters long
specification: Contains charantin which helps lower blood glucose levels. Fruits become more bitter as they mature and turn orange.

use: Flowers used for garlands and religious offerings. Leaves used in traditional medicine for sciatica and arthritis.
careTips: Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Protect from frost in northern regions.
storageTips: Flowers are highly perishable. Leaves can be dried and stored for medicinal use.
growthForm: Large shrub or small tree growing up to 10 meters tall
specification: Flowers bloom at night and drop in the morning. Orange flower tubes with white petals create a distinctive appearance.

use: Pods used as vegetable. Leaves, flowers, and seeds are edible and highly nutritious. Used in traditional medicine.
careTips: Can be grown as annual or perennial. Prune regularly to promote branching. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Fresh leaves last 3-4 days in refrigeration. Can be dried and powdered for longer storage.
growthForm: Fast-growing deciduous tree up to 12 meters tall
specification: Known as 'Miracle Tree' due to exceptional nutritional content. All parts of the plant are usable and beneficial.

use: Used in religious ceremonies associated with Lord Shiva. Used externally in traditional medicine for pain relief.
careTips: Keep away from children and pets due to high toxicity. Can become invasive in some areas.
storageTips: Not recommended for home storage due to high toxicity.
growthForm: Shrubby annual or short-lived perennial growing up to 1.5 meters tall
specification: Highly toxic if ingested. Contains tropane alkaloids that can cause hallucinations, severe toxicity, and death.

use: Leaves used as spice in Indian cooking. Also used in traditional medicine for digestion and diabetes.
careTips: Protect from frost. Apply balanced fertilizer during growing season. Prune to maintain shape.
storageTips: Dried leaves can be stored in airtight containers for up to a year, away from direct light.
growthForm: Evergreen tree growing up to 20 meters tall
specification: Different from European bay leaf (Laurus nobilis). Has three prominent veins running along the length of the leaf.

use: Seeds used as spice in cooking and for medicinal purposes, particularly for digestive disorders.
waterNeeds: Moderate; keep soil consistently moist until established
careTips: Sow directly in well-draining soil. Thin seedlings to 30 cm apart. Harvest when seeds turn brownish-gray.
storageTips: Store dried seeds in airtight containers in cool, dry place for up to 3 years.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 1-1.5 meters tall
specification: Contains thymol which gives it distinctive aroma and medicinal properties. Often used in chutneys and pickles.

use: Popular houseplant believed to bring wealth and prosperity. Also purifies indoor air.
waterNeeds: Moderate; allow top inch of soil to dry between watering
careTips: Grows well in hanging baskets or climbing up moss poles. Prune to control size and promote bushiness.
storageTips: Not applicable for storage; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Evergreen vine with heart-shaped variegated leaves
specification: Mildly toxic if ingested. Can grow up to 20 meters in natural habitat. Easy to propagate from stem cuttings.

use: Popular houseplant known for air purification qualities. Tolerates low light and irregular watering.
careTips: Avoid overwatering as it's susceptible to root rot. Wipe leaves occasionally to remove dust.
storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Evergreen perennial with upright, sword-like leaves
specification: Also called Mother-in-Law's Tongue. Removes toxins like formaldehyde and benzene from air.

use: Leaves used as garnish and in chutneys. Seeds used as spice. Has digestive benefits.
careTips: Sow seeds directly as it doesn't transplant well. Harvest leaves regularly to delay bolting.
storageTips: Fresh leaves last about a week in refrigerator. Seeds can be dried and stored for years.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 50 cm tall
specification: Whole plant is edible - leaves, stems, seeds and roots. Quick-growing crop ready in 3-4 weeks.

use: Popular succulent believed to bring good luck and prosperity. Often gifted for housewarmings.
careTips: Allow soil to dry completely between watering. Prune to maintain shape. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Evergreen succulent with thick, glossy leaves
specification: Also called Money Plant or Dollar Plant. Can live for decades with proper care.

use: Fruits used in cooking for heat and flavor. Contains capsaicin with pain-relieving properties.
waterNeeds: Moderate; water when topsoil is dry
careTips: Support plants with stakes when fruiting. Harvest regularly to encourage more production.
storageTips: Fresh chilies last about a week refrigerated. Can be dried or frozen for longer storage.
growthForm: Annual shrub growing up to 1 meter tall
specification: Many varieties grown in India from mild to extremely hot. Includes popular types like Guntur and Kashmiri.

use: Popular indoor plant known for air purification and elegant white flowers. Helps remove toxins from air.
waterNeeds: Moderate; water when soil feels dry
careTips: Dust leaves regularly. Repot when rootbound. Remove spent flowers to encourage new blooms.
storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Herbaceous perennial with glossy leaves and white spathes
specification: Dramatic drooping when thirsty makes watering needs obvious. NASA-certified air purifier.

use: Fruits used widely in Indian cuisine. Rich in lycopene with antioxidant properties.
careTips: Provide support for vines. Remove suckers for better fruit production. Rotate crops annually.
storageTips: Store ripe tomatoes at room temperature. Can be preserved as sauce, paste or sun-dried.
growthForm: Annual vine growing up to 2 meters tall
specification: Many varieties grown in India including cherry, roma and beefsteak types. Technically a fruit but used as vegetable.

use: Fruits used for juice, flavoring and medicinal purposes. High in vitamin C.

careTips: Fertilize regularly with citrus-specific fertilizer. Protect from frost. Prune to maintain size.
storageTips: Fruits can be stored at room temperature or refrigerated. Juice can be frozen.
growthForm: Small evergreen tree growing up to 2-3 meters
specification: Popular dwarf varieties suitable for container growing. Flowers are fragrant and attract pollinators.

use: Popular hanging plant known for air purification and easy propagation via plantlets.

storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Herbaceous perennial with arching leaves and dangling plantlets
specification: One of the easiest houseplants to grow. Effective at removing formaldehyde from indoor air.

use: Popular indoor palm that adds tropical feel to spaces. Helps humidify indoor air.
careTips: Mist leaves regularly. Wipe leaves to remove dust. Fertilize during growing season.
storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Clustering palm with feathery fronds growing up to 2-3 meters indoors
specification: Also called Butterfly Palm. NASA-certified air purifier. Prefers humid conditions.

use: Leaves used for flavoring and medicinal purposes, especially for cough and cold relief.

storageTips: Fresh leaves last about a week refrigerated. Can be dried for longer storage.
growthForm: Succulent perennial herb growing up to 1 meter tall
specification: Also called Cuban Oregano. Leaves have strong oregano-like flavor with hint of thyme.

use: Flowers used in religious ceremonies, perfumes, and traditional medicine. Rose water used in cooking.

careTips: Prune after flowering. Remove dead wood. Watch for pests like aphids and black spot.
storageTips: Fresh flowers last a few days. Petals can be dried for potpourri or made into rose water.
growthForm: Deciduous shrub with thorny stems growing up to 2 meters
specification: Many traditional Indian varieties with strong fragrance. Flowers used in Ayurvedic preparations.

use: Flowers used for fragrance, relaxation, and in traditional medicine for anxiety relief.

growthForm: Aromatic perennial shrub growing up to 1 meter tall
specification: Essential oil has calming properties. Flowers attract pollinators like bees and butterflies.

use: Leaves used as culinary herb and in traditional medicine for respiratory ailments.

careTips: Harvest leaves before flowering for best flavor. Divide plants every few years to rejuvenate.

growthForm: Perennial herb growing up to 60 cm tall
specification: Contains thymol and carvacrol with antimicrobial properties. Flavor intensifies when dried.

use: Leafy green used in saag, curries, and parathas. Rich in iron and calcium for bone health.

growthForm: Annual leafy vegetable growing up to 30 cm tall
specification: Traditional winter crop in North India. Contains oxalic acid which reduces when cooked.

use: Leaves used fresh/dried in curries. Seeds for tempering and diabetes management.

storageTips: Dry leaves can be stored for months. Seeds last 2-3 years in airtight containers.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 60 cm tall
specification: Sprouted seeds (methi microgreens) are highly nutritious. Traditional galactagogue for nursing mothers.

use: Pods used in sambar, stir-fries, and kurma. Mucilage aids digestion.

growthForm: Annual flowering plant growing up to 2 meters
specification: Heat-loving crop with varieties like Pusa Sawani. Flowers resemble hibiscus (same family).

use: Fruits used in baingan bharta, curries. Nasunin in skin is potent antioxidant.

careTips: Stake plants to support heavy fruits. Rotate crops to prevent verticillium wilt.
storageTips: Store at cool room temperature (not fridge). Best used within 2-3 days of harvest.
growthForm: Perennial grown as annual, up to 1.5 meters tall
specification: Many Indian varieties: round purple (Bharwa), long green (Hyderabad), and tiny pea brinjal.

use: Ornamental plant with large glossy leaves. Removes indoor air pollutants.
waterNeeds: Moderate; let soil dry between watering
careTips: Wipe leaves monthly to remove dust. Prune top to encourage bushiness. Avoid cold drafts.
storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Evergreen tree up to 2-3 meters indoors
specification: Sap was historically used for rubber production. Burgundy varieties popular in Indian homes.

use: Low-maintenance houseplant believed to bring prosperity. Thrives in neglect.
careTips: Overwatering is main killer. Tolerates fluorescent lighting. Dust leaves occasionally.
storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Herbaceous perennial with glossy pinnate leaves
specification: Drought-resistant due to rhizomes that store water. All parts are mildly toxic if ingested.

use: Flowers offered to deities. Used in hair oils and herbal teas for hypertension.

storageTips: Fresh flowers last 1 day. Dry petals for tea in shade and store airtight.
growthForm: Evergreen shrub up to 3 meters tall
specification: National flower of Malaysia. Double-petal varieties popular in temple offerings.

use: Trailing vine for shelves/walls. Removes formaldehyde from air.
waterNeeds: Low; let soil dry between watering
careTips: Trim long vines to encourage fullness. Can grow in water indefinitely.
storageTips: Not applicable; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Evergreen vine with heart-shaped leaves
specification: Variegated varieties (Golden Pothos) brighten dim corners. One of most forgiving houseplants.

use: Leaves for Italian dishes and Thai curries. Essential oil has anti-microbial properties.
careTips: Pinch off flower buds to prolong leaf production. Grow indoors in winters.
storageTips: Freeze leaves in oil or dry them. Fresh lasts 1 week in fridge with stems in water.
growthForm: Annual herb up to 60 cm tall
specification: Different from holy basil (Tulsi). Large-leaf Genovese type used in pesto.

use: Culinary herb for meats/stews. Thymol in oil is potent antiseptic.

careTips: Prune woody stems to encourage new growth. Prefers slightly alkaline soil.
storageTips: Dry sprigs upside down. Store leaves whole to retain flavor, crush when needed.
growthForm: Perennial subshrub up to 30 cm tall
specification: Creeping varieties make aromatic ground cover. Flowers attract bees.

use: Garnish and flavoring. High in vitamin K for blood clotting.
careTips: Soak seeds overnight to speed germination. Biennial but grown as annual.
storageTips: Store stems in water in fridge like flowers. Can be frozen in oil cubes.
growthForm: Biennial herb up to 30 cm tall
specification: Two types: flat-leaf (Italian) and curly. Former has stronger flavor.

use: Leaves/flavor pickles (dill pickles). Seeds for digestive tea.
careTips: Plant away from fennel to prevent cross-pollination. Stake tall varieties.
storageTips: Freeze leaves in water cubes. Dry seeds in paper bags before storing.
growthForm: Annual herb up to 1.5 meters tall
specification: Feathery leaves are larval food for swallowtail butterflies.

use: Mild onion-flavored garnish. Contains allicin with cardiovascular benefits.

storageTips: Refrigerate in damp paper towel. Freeze chopped leaves in oil.
growthForm: Perennial bulb-forming herb up to 50 cm tall
specification: Edible purple flowers attract pollinators. Cold-hardy and deer-resistant.

use: Aromatic herb for meats/breads. Improves memory and concentration.
careTips: Prune lightly but regularly. Avoid wet feet in monsoon. Grows well in containers.
storageTips: Dry sprigs or freeze in oil. Fresh lasts 3 weeks in fridge wrapped in damp cloth.
growthForm: Perennial woody shrub up to 1.5 meters tall
specification: Blue flowers attract bees. Prostrate varieties good for rock gardens.

use: Thanksgiving stuffing herb. Sage tea for sore throats.

careTips: Prune woody stems in spring. Prefers poor, rocky soil over rich compost.
storageTips: Leaves dry well. Store whole leaves in glass jars away from light.
growthForm: Perennial subshrub up to 60 cm tall
specification: Variegated (tricolor) varieties popular for ornamental use. Flowers attract hummingbirds.

use: Aromatic leaves for biryanis and stews. Helps regulate blood sugar.

careTips: Prune to shape as topiary. Protect from cold winds. Slow grower.

growthForm: Evergreen tree up to 12 meters tall
specification: Ancient symbol of wisdom. Leaves used in Greek/Roman laurel wreaths.

use: Ayurvedic brain tonic. Promotes wound healing and vein health.

storageTips: Fresh leaves best. Can be dried but loses potency quickly.
growthForm: Perennial creeping herb
specification: Called 'Brahmi' in North India. Different from Bacopa monnieri (true Brahmi).

use: National fruit of India. Fruits eaten fresh or processed. Leaves, bark, and seeds used in traditional medicine.

careTips: Prune to maintain shape. Protect from frost. Apply potassium-rich fertilizer during fruiting season.

growthForm: Large evergreen tree growing up to 35-40 meters tall
specification: Over 1000 varieties grown in India. King of fruits with unique chemical profile of terpenes.

growthForm: Deciduous shrub or small tree growing up to 5-8 meters
specification: Symbol of fertility and abundance. Juice contains punicalagins with potent antioxidant activity.

use: Fruits rich in vitamin C. Leaves used for diarrhea treatment and diabetes management.
careTips: Prune after fruiting to maintain shape. Protect fruits from fruit flies and birds with netting.

growthForm: Evergreen shrub or small tree growing up to 3-10 meters
specification: Both white and pink flesh varieties popular in India. Young leaves contain quercetin and other flavonoids.

specification: Protected species in India. Heartwood develops fragrance after 15-20 years of growth.

growthForm: Evergreen tree growing up to 30 meters tall
specification: Purple-black fruits with astringent taste. Seeds contain jamboline which helps lower blood sugar.

specification: Contains over 50 herbs with Amla as primary ingredient. Ancient formula mentioned in Charaka Samhita.

specification: Not actually a tree but world's largest herb. Dies after fruiting but produces new suckers.

specification: Called 'Amrita' (nectar of immortality) in ancient texts. Most potent when growing on neem trees.

specification: Contains steviol glycosides that are 300 times sweeter than sugar but without calories.

specification: Name means 'she who possesses a hundred husbands' referring to its fertility-enhancing properties.

specification: Seeds are toxic and should not be consumed. Fruit has custard-like texture when ripe.

specification: Root has vanilla-like fragrance. Called 'False Sarsaparilla' as it's used similarly to American sarsaparilla.

specification: Known as 'King of Bitters' due to intense bitter taste. Major component of Ayurvedic formula 'Sudarshan Churna'.

growthForm: Evergreen shrub growing up to 3 meters tall
specification: Contains alkaloid vasicine which helps dilate bronchial passages. White flowers resemble snapdragons.

use: Sweet fruit with custard-like flesh. Seeds used externally for lice treatment.
careTips: Same as Sitaphal (alternative name for same plant). Hand pollination improves yield.
storageTips: Highly perishable; consume within 2-3 days of ripening. Can be refrigerated briefly.
growthForm: Semi-deciduous small tree growing up to 8 meters tall
specification: Segment-like fruit structure gives it scaly appearance. Contains significant vitamin C and potassium.

use: Leaves used as flavoring in South Indian cuisine. Used medicinally for diabetes and digestive issues.
careTips: Fertilize every 2-3 months. Prune to maintain shape. May drop leaves in winter.
storageTips: Fresh leaves can be refrigerated for up to two weeks. Can be dried or frozen for longer storage.
growthForm: Small evergreen tree growing up to 4-6 meters tall
specification: Contains alkaloids that stimulate digestive enzymes. Aromatic leaves have distinct curry-like fragrance.

use: Flowers used in religious offerings. Leaves used for sciatica, arthritis, and fever.
careTips: Prune after flowering season to maintain shape. Protect from frost in northern regions.
storageTips: Flowers highly perishable. Leaves can be dried and stored for medicinal use.
growthForm: Large shrub or small tree growing up to 10 meters tall
specification: Flowers bloom at night and drop in morning. Called 'Tree of Sorrow' due to this habit.

use: Seeds used in sweets and as thickening agent. Bark used for skin disorders in traditional medicine.
careTips: Slow-growing tree that requires little maintenance. Protect saplings from grazing animals.
storageTips: Seeds can be stored for months in cool, dry place. Roasted seeds last longer than raw.
growthForm: Medium-sized deciduous tree growing up to 15 meters tall
specification: Seeds resembling almonds with delicate flavor. Tree has significant cultural importance in tribal areas.

use: Roots used in Ayurveda for hypertension, insomnia, and snake bites.
careTips: Grows best in humus-rich soil. Harvest roots after 2-3 years. Protected species; check regulations.
storageTips: Dried roots can be stored in airtight containers for up to a year away from light.
growthForm: Perennial shrub growing up to 1 meter tall
specification: Contains reserpine, first natural antihypertensive drug isolated. Listed in Red Data Book as endangered.

use: Flower buds used in Ayurveda for skin diseases and bleeding disorders. Wood prized for construction.
careTips: Slow-growing tree that requires minimal maintenance. Protect from frost when young.
storageTips: Dried flower buds can be stored in airtight containers for up to 2 years.
growthForm: Evergreen tree growing up to 35 meters tall
specification: National tree of Sri Lanka. Produces fragrant white flowers with golden centers.

use: Extremely high vitamin C content. Used in Ayurveda for immunity, digestion, and hair health.
careTips: Prune after fruiting. Apply organic manure annually. Protect from strong winds.
storageTips: Fresh fruits last 1-2 weeks in refrigeration. Can be preserved in salt water or made into preserves.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 18 meters tall
specification: One of three ingredients in Triphala. Remains fresh long after harvesting due to tannin content.

use: Wood valued for furniture. Leaves used in traditional medicine for skin diseases.
careTips: Prune to maintain shape. Watch for pests like defoliators and borers.
storageTips: Not applicable for home storage as it's primarily grown for timber.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 25 meters tall
specification: Fast-growing species that helps prevent soil erosion. Wood has distinctive grain pattern.

use: Root used as women's tonic in Ayurveda. Beneficial for female reproductive system.
careTips: Provide trellis for climbing. Harvest roots after 2 years. Plant in well-draining soil.
storageTips: Dried roots can be stored in airtight containers away from light for up to 2 years.
growthForm: Climbing herb with feathery foliage and small thorns
specification: Related to but different from vegetable asparagus. Contains saponins with medicinal properties.

use: Bulbs used as spice and for cardiovascular health. Natural antibiotic and antiviral.
waterNeeds: Moderate; stop watering when tops begin to yellow
careTips: Plant cloves in late autumn. Harvest when tops fall over. Cure before storage.
storageTips: Store in cool, dry place with good air circulation. Can be braided by stems for hanging.
growthForm: Bulbous herb growing up to 60 cm tall
specification: Contains allicin which gives it antimicrobial properties. Best planted near roses to repel pests.

use: Rhizome used as spice and for nausea, inflammation, and cold treatment.
careTips: Plant pieces with growth buds facing up. Mulch heavily. Harvest 8-10 months after planting.
storageTips: Fresh rhizomes can be refrigerated for 3 weeks. Can be dried, pickled, or frozen.
growthForm: Herbaceous perennial growing from rhizome up to 1 meter tall
specification: Contains gingerol which gives it pungent flavor and anti-inflammatory properties.

use: Fruit used for digestive disorders, dysentery, and diabetes. Sacred to Lord Shiva.
careTips: Prune to maintain shape. Fertilize annually. Protect young plants from frost.
storageTips: Fresh fruit can be stored up to 2 weeks. Pulp can be dried or made into preserves.
growthForm: Deciduous thorny tree growing up to 15 meters tall
specification: Hard-shelled fruit with aromatic pulp. Slow-growing but can live for over 100 years.

use: Leaves used in chutneys, beverages, and for digestive issues. Has cooling properties.
careTips: Contains invasive runners; best grown in containers. Pinch regularly to promote bushiness.
storageTips: Fresh leaves last 1 week refrigerated in damp paper towel. Can be frozen or dried.
growthForm: Aromatic perennial herb spreading by runners
specification: Contains menthol which gives cooling sensation. Repels insects naturally.

use: Fruit used in Ayurveda for digestive disorders and as gentle laxative. Component of Triphala.
careTips: Minimal pruning required. Add compost annually. Protect from frost when young.
storageTips: Dried fruits can be stored for years in airtight containers.
growthForm: Large deciduous tree growing up to 30 meters tall
specification: Called 'King of Medicines' in Tibet. Rich in tannins and antioxidants.

use: Fruit used in Ayurveda for respiratory conditions and eye disorders. Component of Triphala.
careTips: Similar to Harad. Requires minimal maintenance once established.
storageTips: Dried fruits can be stored for years in airtight containers away from moisture.
growthForm: Large deciduous tree growing up to 30 meters tall
specification: Contains gallic acid and ellagic acid with antioxidant properties. Seeds are narcotic if consumed in large quantities.
